segments.text: that 15 seconds.
That's so that you won't miss something on the tape.
I don't know.

Now, then I don't think, I think if you're not subscribing to the idea, which appears frequently in the press, that the only way American fishermen can compete is to go into this kind of mass market fishing of the Russian and the Japanese, that is sending out floating cities in effect.
The fact is the
My own viewpoint is that would be an economic catastrophe.
I don't think they can compete that way.
I don't think, in essence, by the way, I don't think world fisheries are now moving in that direction.
If one takes a close examination in an economic sense in Europe
and many other areas of those fishes that are really profitable.
It's sort of the middle distant type of vessel.
A vessel that's big enough to get out and have a reasonable operational range, but largely is essentially delivering to a local port in a particular region.
And I think vessels of the class from 100 to 150 feet are going to be the dominant element of producing fish over the next
20 years, and I think that's for where most of your fish is going to come from.

I think there's a lot of economic problems of taking large numbers of people to sea and maintaining them at sea, energy costs and other things that are going to essentially drive them out of that sort of business.

I only have one more question now along this line before I return back to sort of a biographical approach, but I take it you think the 200-mile limit was a wise decision on the part of the government.
Well,
I was very strongly in favor of the 200-mile limit, in spite of the fact that many of my colleagues in academia and elsewhere opposed it.
Basically, I have felt that some sort of system had to come into existence where
some entity was responsible.
As it was, I saw just an international conflict.
And although there were a lot of international commissions, they really didn't have the backbone or the authority to make the decisions.
There was a great deal of procrastination.
And I've been involved with many of these commissions.
And I'd seen one fishery after the other throughout the world going into a depleted phase, many of which were under the commissions.
And the institutional arrangements, their terms of reference, in my view, just didn't allow for them to essentially achieve sound conservation.
So I think at least as a first step, I felt that somebody had to gain control and set up an institutional mechanism that decisions could be made in a reasonable time frame.
Now all of those decisions I'm going to admit are not going to be as rational as we would like them.
There's going to be politics involved to certain extent.
There's going to be loose use of the data in terms of achievement, parochial interest.
Now I'm on as the
a scientific advisor and chairman for the North Pacific Council and also for the Pacific Council, I'll remember.
And I think those scientific groups can have a tremendous impact on whether or not we ultimately are going to have a rational fisheries.
Because one, they're independent.
You know, they're not getting instructions from anybody, from their agencies or from the consul itself.
And several instances already, our groups have come out in conflict with a consul decision that we thought was politically oriented and not associated with the facts.
And I think the consul perceives it's going to be very difficult for them to essentially win in the courts.
if the scientific advisory group has essentially come down in a very negative way on a particular approach.
So I think the structure allows an opportunity to manage much more effectively than we have in the past.
I am afraid of one thing, and that's that politics at a parochial level will not allow us to reach the intent of the law
And that is, and I'll make it very clear, I don't want to see a law that essentially ends up forcing a lot of foreigners out of resources that we really aren't going to use.
Waste of a large amount of food and raw material that's needed by many people in the world just to achieve some selfish local interest.
If that happens, then ultimately I guess I'll feel that maybe I supported...
a wrong type of institutional arrangement.
But at this point in time, even though the councils have a lot of problems, I still look favorably on the arrangement.
The law needs to be changed in certain ways, but nevertheless, I favor the 200 mile, and I think it's ultimately going to be
serve mankind better than the sort of free-for-all we had before.
It may eventually, by the way, evolve into something else.
And fine, if it does under some sort of proper controlled system, then I'll support it.
And I think we do need the international input and cooperation.
But at the time, and under the situation we were under, when the law came into existence, I fully supported it, and I still do.
Now, during this period of your career, then, you're going back to graduate school and you're really working as associate director of the fisheries.
No, at that time I was director of the exploratory fisheries group when I'm going back to graduate school.
That's from starting in, I guess, about 60 through 67 that I was going.
graduate school.
Yeah, you finished your PhD in 67.
Right.
And then when you become associate director of fisheries?
That's right.
At that time, I was asked by the director of the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries if I'd come back and essentially become an associate in terms of research, associate director for research.
Those were rather ill times for me because I went through some very difficult
mental strain and also problems in terms of what involved to me integrity in government.
I'd gone back under Mr. Crowther, who was director, who within a very short time frame was essentially removed as director of the thing.
I was asked to take over the directorship, but in a manner that almost
made it impossible for me to do that.
Before Mr. Crowther was essentially fired,
a high official under the Hickle regime came and asked me if I would take over the job if they would fire my boss, who was one of my very good friends.
And, you know, if suddenly the job had been there and somebody said, Lee, will you come back and take this job, I probably would have taken the job.
But for somebody to come in and say, you know, if I fire your friend, Mr. Crowther, you can further your career, put me in a very difficult position.
And

Because of other things I saw going down, I had a major run-in, a very interesting aspect of my career, with an assistant secretary for interior at that time named Dunn, whose wife was a cousin to President Nixon.
and who came out to visit here in Seattle.
I was out in Seattle.
That was the time I was stationed in Washington, but I was out in Seattle.
And I had gone down with some other people to meeting at the airport.
And he'd been drinking and got off the plane and acted pretty much like I was his manservant, like telling me, go get my bags and deliver them to the hotel.
I don't cotton to that thing very easily.
And I told the secretary, well, if he wanted somebody to get his bags, he better get a manservant.
Or he had better ask me, please, I'll help anybody carry his bag.
I had to help the janitor carry his bag.
But on the other hand, I don't want somebody coming and telling me, pick up my bag, boy, and I'll meet you at the hotel type of thing.
So I came very close to being fired as a result of that.
But I just hung it out.
said that I wasn't going to apologize.
And I felt that if there was any apology due, it was due to me.
And ultimately, Mr. Hickel called me personally and asked me about that.
And apparently, he and Mr. Dunn didn't get along too well together.
I'm not sure about that.
But anyway, I got a call from them.
in essence, said, forget about the problem.
And it was erased from the books.
And very shortly after that, Mr. Pickle was resigned or removed, whatever one wants to look at that.
And Mr. Dunn was removed from the department also.
So that sort of trauma was over.
But by the time that had happened, and I had this invitation to take over the job, and because of the various
And I'll just call it political intrigue that I saw going on, even at middle management level in Washington.
I decided at that time that I didn't want to have anything to do with it and asked to come back to Seattle.
So my tenure there was relatively short.
I did act as acting director for the department of Bureau of Commercial Fishery after Mr. Crowther left.
I told the department people I would do that until such time as they found a replacement.
for Mr. Crowther, and then I returned to Seattle.
OK. And so you're really only there, best I can figure out from reading your vitae, you were really only there a year.
Is that right?
That's about right.
And much of that, by the way, I was doing a lot of commuting between Seattle and Washington.
So I guess an actual stay in Washington was closer to six months.
So I washed out rather quickly.
If one has a choice between DC and Seattle, there's no choice, believe me.
Seattle's a lot better.
So when you return back to Seattle now, I assume then you're simply transferred down here.
Is this fair to say?
I transferred back to a new slot they had set up, which was sort of an associate regional director for research.
For resource planning, a resource program.
title of it myself, but it was really for taking care of the research program.
Okay, that's what I wanted to know.
I wonder what you did, because that title implies nothing.
Yeah, that is typical of many government titles.

In essence, what it was is I was responsible for essentially coordinating the total research program in the region, developing the programs and designing the programs and working with the various, at that time, roughly five laboratory directors and putting the research program together here in the region.
Okay, now, what kind of programs did you try to put together?
Well, we had a whole range of them.
At that time, sort of my horizons were broadened.
I had to deal with marine mammal programs, research in marine mammals.
I had to deal with our basic program in oceanography and fisheries oceanography.
Here are high seas fisheries research.
I had to deal with programs that still related to exploratory fishing, gear technology.
So it was the whole gamut.
of research in terms of the broad range of things you might think that we do under the broad umbrella of oceanography, from fisheries biology to physical oceanography to chemical oceanography.
So designing programs throughout the North Pacific that dealt with the federal involvement in fisheries and oceanography.
Did you have any long-range goal?
Is that a fair question?
When you came into the job, did you have something in mind that you wanted to accomplish?
Into that particular job?
Into that particular job.
Yeah.
I very much wanted to establish the so-called center concept that now exists in the United States.

At that time, we had a whole series of fragmented labs throughout the US, each with an independent program and each one going its independent direction with a tremendous amount of overlapping programs between labs.
And if you wanted an answer in terms of somebody's response, for example, what's the consequence of an oil spill in area X?
Or what should our position be in terms of what's the technical information to develop a position for negotiating with Japan?
You ended up having to run to five different labs that might have five different views because they were unconsolidated.
They were independent, autonomous structures.
And a great deal of overlap, in my view, waste of energy and funds in terms
of an agency that has a pretty directed mission.

You know, you can think of one thing if you want to run a university that way is quite different than running a government organization that has some direct applied types of information that must be developed on almost an annual basis in terms of response to basic problems that the government's confronted with.
I didn't see that.
I saw a waste of people were buying the same facilities and duplicate them.
Each lab had the same number of Nansen bottles but was using them once a year for one crew.
Each lab had
and was trying to duplicate.

None of the labs, by the way, were well essentially equipped in terms of the type of equipment that one needs to do science and the computer backup, the computer facilities, the electronic systems and things that are needed to be done.
And I felt if we could aggregate these into a series of labs that would deal with science, not in telling this scientist what the hell he's going to produce,
But in a sense, bringing together these people to develop an overall set of scientific programs within a region to be responsive to these regions.
That one, we'd have the mass.
One, we could attract better scientists because we could essentially develop better facilities in these particular institutions.
So a lot of science won't go to a place where there aren't the appropriate facilities.
It can be good living in Seattle.
But if you haven't got a good electron microscope, I'm not going to get anybody that's interested in that particular field in this area, even if it's a big problem.
And if I don't have the computer system for the people that are doing population dynamics and modeling to essentially use as a tool, they're going to go someplace where they can.
And none of the labs could provide that.

So the concept and goal was here is to collect these together into a set of major centers that would essentially have facilities much like many of the universities do so that we could attract damn good students coming out of universities.
I see an awful lot of university people were turning right back to university in terms of careers.

either into teaching or into various institutions the university would think, because they had the facilities, they had the environment that you couldn't generate in most of the government laboratories.
And I guess that was one of my major goals.
Along with my own interest, of course, as a scientist, I have always had a major interest in the area of animal population dynamics, and I've always felt that I have to have...
at least 37% of my time to allocate to my own special interests.

Because I have a very strong feeling about government scientists and that it's very easy to get in and become so caught up in administration that quite quickly you essentially come out of the scientific world.
And then the real reason that you were put in there as a leader, because other scientists recognize you, other scientists would work for you, you lose.
Because you're no longer a scientist.

So I have really had a very strong dedication that I'm going to essentially continue in my own particular error and continue to publish in that error a sufficient amount so that I have that recognition and acceptance in terms of the scientific community.
I'm not sure that happens in all government labs.
I'm sure it does not.
But I have felt as a personal conviction
that that's one of my long-range goals is to always essentially be sufficiently alert to my own field that I am capable of publishing and writing in that field.
That's great.
I support that wholeheartedly.
It's not easy to do.
Not easy to do, right.
If you're an administrator, I find it great.
I find it difficult to understand how you find the time for that.
Well, I guess...
Like many of the people in the field, my sort of vacation even at home is taking a pen and relaxing and sitting down and working on a paper that I like.
I don't do much writing in the office here anymore, but I still manage to get three to four papers a year and credible journals.
And I guess I do 60% to 70% of that at home.
And it's sort of a relaxation to me to be able to sit down at home
pull some papers, particularly it gets me away from the day-to-day administrative problems.

I think a lot of scientists end up in these things and really don't know what they're getting into, and then find out they're dealing with people and people problems, and they're sort of getting aced out of the whole area that they were trained for.
I have a couple of specific technical questions I'd like to ask you.
Now, deep sea trawlers is really what this concerns.
What sort of technological changes do you think need to take place, if any, before you can draw better biological samples on deep sea trawlers?
in terms of, are you talking about kind of research?
Yeah, if you wanted to draw a representative sample of deep sea populations, for example, that's what many fisheries are now trying to do.
And it seems, at least to us, that those of us on the outside
that biologically, not a very good job is being done about that.
Well, let's see.
I think the best jobs is being done that one can do with deep sea trawls and deep sea nets of the type we have now.
But you're quite correct.
Interpreting what that really means is one hell of a problem.
And in fact, this is going to be a scenario I've written on in a great deal, and this deals with what I
like to call the coefficient of catchability of these things.
For each species, it differs.
For each species within different age groups, it differs.
In other words, that net, even if the animal is in front of it, will take a different proportion of
of three-year-olds and it will four-year-olds.
One group is stronger, slightly average size.
It'll differ between species because of their swimming capabilities and their avoidance responses, their behavioral responses.
They have different behavioral patterns.
So you get a conglomerate in what I call in terms of a net sample.
Ultimately, and I think it addresses your question, really
doesn't tell you a great deal about what was really there when the net went through.
You know, how representative is that, and how well can you reconstruct the original population?

And probably not very well, with the exception of, oh, I would say a half a dozen species that we're beginning to get a fairly good fix on the coefficient of catchability, at least for certain size groups.
But even here, you know, it changes between seasons.
The animals are more active during one season than another.
They're more likely to be up off the bottom in one season than in another.
They're more likely to be off the bottom at night than they are in the day.
So it is one tremendous problem.
And I guess what one is looking for and what we're shooting for down the line is the addition of electronic sensing equipment that not necessarily catches what's in front of the net.
The concept of electrical trawls and things have been introduced.
That perhaps will work out, but I see a whole set of problems that have generated that.
I think it's more important to have some sort of remote instrumentation that really gives you a continuing fix on these set of coefficients that we have to deal with.
I think this can be done to some extent acoustically now.
I tell you, the people that are really taking a leadership role in this are the people over at Lowestoft England.
who have various acoustical arrays that are essentially telling them how many of the fish that are in front of the net and over a certain path are ending up in the net.
And they're doing this two ways.
in terms of passive and direct acoustics.
They've got very small acoustical devices now that they put on a number of fish that they capture, release back into the environment.
Then they know where those fish are.
They've spotted those fish.
They can put the trawl down, and they can say, all right, there's 10 of those fish in front of my trawl, because they've got them acoustically on their array.
And they pass the trawl through and say, we've got two of them.
And then they go through and do that again, and they say,
Well, on an average, the coefficient of catchability of this particular species at these particular size groups, and they're doing this during different seasons of the year, are about x.
Now, that's a start, but it's a very tedious and costly way to go about it.
Ultimately, I guess we're really going to have some sort of instrumentation that's reasonable in terms of cost that's going to essentially be scanning across the front of the
sample the trawl net in terms of the path that's being sampled, and ultimately saying, you know, that you're losing X number of fish of X species.
That's not going to be easy to do.
I doubt if I see it, you know, in my lifetime.
But I guess that's ultimately where you're going to have to go if you're going to use trawl sampling.
Whether or not independent acoustical techniques ever get to that stage, I don't know.
There's a real problem in the physics of essentially target identification.
Detecting the animal is easy.
And now even getting a good understanding of the size of that animal is relatively easy by the amount of energy that's returning from the target.
and the characteristics of the blip.
One knows pretty well it's a fish.
It's a fish of this size.
It's a fish with an air bladder.
It's a fish without an air bladder.
But still saying it is a cod, it is a black cod, it's a halibut, et cetera, we're a long way from that.
They're working on that.
And if that's ever overcome, then acoustical assessment could be a major technique that will improve our ability to assess the ocean resources.
Well, that may well have answered the next question, which I was going to ask.
And it seemed, when we looked at your papers, most of them are on such things as distribution, migration, systematics of ecology and growth of marine fishes.
How should research be expanded into that area?
I mean, given the unreliability of data, would acoustical soundings, is that what you suggest as the major development?
I only bring acoustics forward as one new tool.
But I think one has to be careful.
I think reliance on any one tool is not an appropriate way for the scientists to go forward.
I think we're going to have to continue
with a wide variety of net sampling from everything from our standard one meter plankton nets to bongo nets to a variety of trawls and persains and craps and a whole range of sampling techniques.
I think we'd like to broaden our direct observation through television and
And I think we'll learn a lot from scuba divers.
I don't think the use of scuba divers has been made as scientific as it should.
It's been sort of a random set of observations and photography.
I think that could be improved.
But I think remote sensing and direct sensing are going to add a dimension between now and the end of the century that's far ahead of anything we've got.
If you see some of the things that

that are coming out and available to the people in the oil industry and can be termed and applied in terms of some of our problems in fisheries and fishery science, they'll add a great dimension to this.
And I really think that where we're going, at least over the next 10 years, of course, is getting out of this sort of single fisheries or focus into really more into an ecosystem focus.
And this then, of course, does demand you look across
much broader range of animals.
All right, now that's the next question.
What management theories then are you leading to with these kinds of studies?
And clearly you're leading to a management theory of an ecosystem.
What is it?
Okay, I want to be careful not to use jargon here.
You know, everybody's talking about ecosystem management, and I think it's a very loose term at this point in our capabilities.
When I sit down and talk to the marine mammal
specialist who said, you know, you guys are wrong in fisheries.
You need to get into ecosystem management.
My answer is, you're right.
Now, where do we go?
Now, that's the question you answer me.
If you turn around and say, what models do you have to tell us to do this?
What set of observations do we have?
Then, you know, we start to skate on pretty thin ice.
We just don't have a hell of a lot
of information in terms of good ecosystem concepts.
Now, here at the center, I've got a special group that's working on ecosystem modeling for the Bering Sea.
And it's the area probably have more data on a broader range of animals than any place in the world.
We have good data on birds.
We've got good data on marine mammals.
We've got good data on the upper trophic level of fish.
We've got good data on plankton, et cetera.
Still, I think we're 10 years away
from a model that has adequate predictive capability to get into the day-to-day management process.
The system is so dynamic, and we can measure so few things in the system at this time, that we're really just guessing.
And I see a hell of a lot of guessing of, in the Antarctic, people are going to fish krill, and it's going to destroy the opportunity for the whales to come back.
And I think a lot of this is

is based on a high degree of emotionalism and also by the way i think it's a tactic to get money we sign issues all sorts of tactics to get money like everybody else and i just hope that the tactic and the emotionalism doesn't overrun our real capabilities in the field there is an opportunity in my view to do a much better management and job in management of our aquatic resources by taking an ecosystem approach

but not taking one in a haphazard sense that says, I'm going to throw everything away I've done because really the single species approach really isn't very good, and now I'm going to go to an ecosystem.
You know, it took us years to develop even some halfway reasonable data to manage single species.
It's going to take us a long time before we really have reached the point where we can say,

If we perturb this, this, and this, these are the likely consequences in the system, particularly when you've got so much noise in the environment that's having a tremendous influence on that complex itself.
So I guess I go forward cautiously saying we must go there.
But I think we have to do it in a very scientific way, and that we oughtn't to just discard a lot of what we already have.
Because really, they represent the only tools we have probably in the short range to give some answers to managers.
In five to 10 years, I think we will start to have models, at least in this part of the world, where we're looking at 25 species at one time and looking at the interactions.
We're building that now, but we're building towards it.
